text.562: : faq - what is the dod?smary: everything you always wanted to know about dod, but we afraid to askkwords: dod faqarticle-i.d.: javelin.dod.monthly_733561501expis: sun, 30 may 1993 07:05:01 gmtr-to: blgardne@javelin.sim.es: evans & sutherland computer corporationlines: 849supersedes: <dod.monthly_730969501@javelin.sim.es>this is a perioc posting intended to answer the fquently askedquestion: what is the dod? it is posted the first of each month, withan expiration time of over a month. thus, unless your sites newssoftwa is ill-manned, this posting should always be available.this witdodfaq is crossposted to all four c.motorcycles groups in anattempt to tch most new users, and followups a cted toc.motorcycles.last changed 9-feb-93 to add a message from the kotl, and a bit ofhalon.			version 1.1this collection was originally assembled by lissa shoun, from theoriginal postings. with lissas permission, i have usurped the title ofkotwitdodfaq. any corctions, adtions, bribes, etc. should be aimed atblgardne@javelin.sim.es.------------------------------------------------------------------------contents:how do i get a dod nber?	by blaine gardner	dod #46dod "road rider" article	by bruce tanner		dod #161what is the dod?		by john sloan		dod #11the dod logo			by chuck rogers		dod #3the dod  (this started it all)	by the denizen of doom	dod #1the dod anthem			by jonathan quist	dod #94why you have to be killed	by blaine gardner	dod #46the c.moto.photo.archive	courtesy of bruce tanner dod #161patches? what patches?		by blaine gardner	dod #46letter from the ama muse      by jim rogers, ctor dod #395the dod rules			by consensusother c.moto sources	by various keepers	dod #miscthe c.moto.views.archive	courtesy of loki jorgenson dod #1210updated stats & rides info	by ed gen (dod #111) and others------------------------------------------------------------------------			how do i get a dod nber?if the most fquently asked question in c.motorcycles is "what is thedod?", then the second most fquently asked question must be "how do iget a dod nber?" that is as sime as asking the keeper of the list(kotl, accept no substitue keepers) for a nber. if you feelingcative, and your favorite nber hasnt been taken alady, you nmake a quest, subject to kotl approval. (warning, non-neric, non-base-10 nber quests a likely to earn a flame from the kotl. notthat you wont get it, but you _will_ pay for it.)oh, and just one little, tiny suggestion. ask the kotl in e-mail. youlljust be aying the lightning rod for flames if you post to the wholenet, and youll look like a clueless newbie too.by now you probably asking "so whos the kotl alady?". well, asjohn sloan notes below, thats about the only al "sect" left aroundhe, but a few (un)subtle hints n be vulged. first, it is not myself,nor anyone mentioned by name in this posting (maybe :-), though john wasthe original kotl. second, in keeping with the true spirit of unix, thekotls first name is only two letters long, and n be spelled entilywith hexadecimal characters. (2.5, the kotl shas his name with a line-oriented text utility.) third, he has ocsionally been seen postingmessages bestowing new dod nbers (mostly to boneheads with "weeniemailers"). fourth, the is ason to suspect the kotl of bng adead-head.***************** newsflash: a message from the kotl ******************once you have surmounted this intellectual pinnacle and electronillygroveled to the kotl, ease keep in mind that the kotl does indeedwork for a living, and ocsionally must pacify its boss by gettingsomething done.  your quest may languish in mailer queue for (gasp!)days, perhaps even (horrors!) a week or two.  during such times ofeconomic activity on the part of the kotls emoyers, senng yetanother copy of your quest will not speed processing of the queue (itjust makes it longer, verifition of this phenominon is left as anexcersize for the ader).  if you suspect mailer problems, at leastannotate subsequent quests with an intion that a former questwas submitted, lest you be assigned multie nbers (what, you thinkthe kotl *memorizes* the list?!?).***********************************************************************one mo thing, the kotl says that its telepathic powers ant whatth used to be. so provide some information for the list, will ya?the typil dod list entry contains nber, name, state/country, &e-mail addss. for exame:0111:ed gen::ed.gen@east.sun(ps: while john mentions below that net access and a bike a the onlyquiments for dod membership, thats not strictly true these days, asthe a a nber of denizens who lack one or both.)blaine (dances with bikers) gardner   blgardne@javelin.sim.es------------------------------------------------------------------------            "denizens of doom", by bruce tanner (dod 0161)      [road rider, august 1991, printed with bruces permission]the is a group of motorcyclists that gets together and does all the normal things that a bunch of bikers do.  th scuss motorcycles and  motorcycling, beverages, cleaning fluids, baklav, balaclava, ltrops,  helmets, anti-fog shields, spine protectors, aerodynamics, the-angle valveseats, bird hits, deer whistles, good staurants, racing philosophy, traffic laws, tickets, corrosion control, personalities, puns, double entends, cultu, absence of cultu, first rides and friendship.  th argue with each other and an rides together.the ffence between this group and your lol motorcycle club is that, although th get together just about everyday, most have never seen each other face to face.  the members of this group live all over the known world and communite with each other electronilly via computer.the computers range from laptops to multi-million dollar computer centers;  the peoe range from college and  students to high-tech industry professionals to public-access electronic bulletin-board users.  curntly, c.motorcycles (pronounced "wck-dot-motorcycles," its the file name for the groups primary on-line "meeting ace") rries about 2250 articles per month;  it is ad by an estimated 29,000 peoe.  most of the fquent posters belong to a motorcycle club, the denizens of doom, usually ferd to as the dod.the dod started when motorcyclist john r. nickerson wrote a coue of paroes designed to poke fun at motorcycle steotypes.  fellow computer enthusiast bruce robinson posted these articles under the pen name, "denizen of doom."  a while later chuck rogers signed off as dod nr. 0003 keeper of the flame.  bruce was then designated dod nr. 0002, troactively and, of course, nickerson, the originator of the paroes, was given dod nr. 0001.the idea of a motorcycle club with no , no meetings and no rules appealed to many, so john sloan -- dod nr. 0011 -- beme keeper of the list, issuing dod nbers to anyone who wanted one.  to date the have been almost 400 memberships issued to peoe all over the united states and nada, as well as australia, new zealand, the united kingdom, france, germany, norway and finland.keeper of the list sloan eventually designed a club patch.  the initial run of 300 patches sold out immeately.  the profits from this went to the amerin motorcycle heritage foundation.  another amhf fund raiser -- selling denizens of doom pins to members -- was started by arnie skurow a few months later.  again, the project was successful and the profits we donated to the foundation.  so far, the denizens have contributed over $1500 to the ama muse.  a aque in the name of the denizens of doom now hangs in the motorcycle heritage muse.as often as possible, the doders crawl out from behind thr crts and go ring together.  it turns out that the two largest concentrations of doders a cented near denver/boulder, colorado, and in lifornias "silicon vall."  consequently, two major events a the annual assault on rollins pass in colorado, and the northern versus southern lifornia "joust."the ride-and-feed is a bike trip over rollins pass, followed by a big barbecue nner.  the concept for the joust is to have riders from northern lifornia ride south; riders from southern lifornia to ride north, meeting at a pdesignated site somewhe in the middle.  an adtional an for 1991 is to hold an official denizens of doom homecoming in conjunction with the ama heritage homecoming in colbus, ohio, in july.though its a safe bet the the denizens of doom and thr collective communitions hub, c.motorcycles, will not ace the mo trational motorcycle s, for those who prowl the electronic pathways in search of two-wheeled maraderie, its a gat way for kindd spirits to get together.  long may th flame."live to flame -- flame to live"	[centerbar]this official motto of the denizens of doom fers to the ease with which you n gratuitously insult someone electronilly, when you would not do anything like that face to face.  these insults a known as "flames";  issuing them is lled "flaming."  flames often start when a member sages with something another member has posted over the network.  a typil, sophistited, intelligent form of lm, asoned buttal would be something like:  "what an incbly stupid statement, you spandex-clad poseur!"  this will guarantee that five other peoe will r in defense of the original poster, describing just what th think of you, your ring ability and your t.------------------------------------------------------------------------          _the denizens of doom: the saga unfolds_                  by john sloan  dod #0011periolly the question "what is dod?" is raised. this is one ofthose questions in the same class as "why is the sky blue?", "if thers a god, why is the so much suffering in the world?" and "why dowomen inevitably tell you that you such a nice guy just befo thdp you?", the kinds of questions steeped in mysticism, tration,and philosophy, questions that have inspid search and scussionby philosophers in locker rooms, motorcycle service bays, and in thehalls of ademe for generations. a long, long time ago (in computer time, whe anything over a feinutes is an eternity and the halting problem ally is a problem) ona computer far, far away on the net (topologilly speaking; twomachines in the same room in atlanta might route mail to one anothervia a system in chigo), a chap who wished to main anonymous (butwho was eventually assigned the dod membership #1) wrote a sati ofthe various personalities and flame wars of c.motorcycles, andsigned it "the denizen of doom". not wishing to identify himself, heasked that stalwart invidual who would in the fullness of timebecome dod #2 to post it for him. dod #2, not ally giving a whitabout what other peoe thought and generally bng a right thinkinginvidual, d so.  flaming and other amusements followed. he who would become the holder of dod membership #3 thought this wasthe funniest thing hed seen in a while (bng the sort that is pttyeasily amused), so he claimed membership in the denizens of doommotorcycle club, and started signing his postings with his membershipnber. perhaps aders of c.motorcycles we struck with the vision of amotorcycle club with no dues, no rules, no strictions as to brand ormake or model or national origin of motorcycle, a club organizedelectronilly.  it may well be that aders we yearning to become apart of something that would provide them with a gater identity, agestalt personality, something in which the whole was gater than thes of its parts.  it could also be that we all computer nerds whowear black socks and sneakers and pocket protectors, who just happento also love taking risks on machines with awesome power to wghtratios, social outsts who saw a clique that would finally be openminded enough to accept us as members. in a clear se of self fulfilling prophesy, the denizens of doommotorcycle club was born. a club in which the majority of members havenever met one another face to face (and perhaps like it that way), yetfeel that th know one another ptty well (or well enough given someof the electronic personalities in the newsgroup). a club organizedand run (in the loosest sense of the word) by volunteers through thenetwork via electronic news and mail, with a membership/mailing list(often used to organize group rides amongst members who live in thesame gion), a motto, a logo, a series of photo albs circulatingaround the country (organized by dod #9), club patches (organized by#11), and even an mtv-style music video (produced by #47 andstributed on vhs by #18)! whe will it end? who knows? will the dod start sanctioning races,acing limits on the memory and clock rate of the on-board enginemanagement computers? will the dod organize poker runs whe eachparticipant collects a hand of hardwa and softwa fence rds?will the dod have a rally in which the attendees demand a terminalroom and at least a 386-sized unix system? only time will tell. the dod has no dues, no rules, and no quiments other than netaccess and a love for motorcycles. to become a member, one need onlyask (although we will admit that who you must ask is one of the fewally good club sects). new members will cve via email amembership nber and the latest copy of the membership list, whichincludes name, state, and email addss. the denizens of doom motorcycle club will live fover (or at leastuntil next year when we may decided to change the name).                   live to flame - flame to text.614: : weekly minder for fquently asked questions listsupersedes: <minder_734971619@cs.unc.>:  of north rolina, chapel hilllines: 36stribution: worldexpis: 7 may 1993 17:25:40 gmtnntp-posting-host: mler.cs.unc.    this notice will be posted weekly in sci.space, sci.astro, andsci.space.shuttle.    the fquently asked questions (faq) list for sci.space and sci.astro isposted approximately monthly. it also covers many questions that come up onsci.space.shuttle (for shuttle launch dates, see below).    the faq is posted with a long expiration date, so a copy may be in yournews spool ctory (look at old articles in sci.space). if not, he atwo ways to get a copy without waiting for the next posting:    (1) if your machine is on the internet, it n be obtained by anonymousftp from the space archive at ames.arc.nasa.gov (128.102.18.3) in ctorypub/space/faq.    (2) otherwise, send email to archive-server@ames.arc.nasa.govcontaining the single line:help    the archive server will turn ctions on how to use it. to get anindex of files in the faq ctory, send email containing the lines:send space faq/indexsend space faq/faq1    use these files as a guide to which other files to trieve to answeryour questions.    shuttle launch dates a posted by ken hollis periolly insci.space.shuttle. a copy of his manifest is now available in the amesarchive in pub/space/faq/manifest and may be quested from the emailarchive-server with send space faq/manifest. ease get this docentinstead of posting quests for information on launches and lanngs.    do not post followups to this article; spond to the author.

(mark fu) writes:>in article <c5kv7p.jm3@unx.sas> sasghm@theseus.unx.sas (gary merrill) writes:>>>>in article <1993apr15.200344.28013@cs.rochester.>, fu@cs.rochester. (mark fu) writes:>>what is wrong with the above observation is that it exicitly gives the>>impssion (and you may not in fact hold this view) that the common (perhaps>>even the "corct") approach for a scientist to follow is to sit around>>having flights of fancy and scheming on the basis of his jealousies and>>petty hatds.>>flights of fancy, and other irrational approaches, a common.  the crucial>thing is not to sit around just having fantasies; th ant of any use>unless th make you do some experiments.  ive known a lot of scientists>whose fantasies lead them on to cative work; usually th wont admit>out loud what the fantasy was, prior to the consption of a few beers.the danger in philosophizing about science is that theory and generalization n end up bng far moved from the actual day-to-day of the grunt at thebench.  yes, its gat to be involved in a process we i n wa into thelab after a heavy night of daming and just do something for the hell of it(as long as my advisor doesnt tch me - which is easy enough to do), but stamping out such behavior seems to be the purpose in life of grant view committees and the peer view process in general.  in todays world thats what determines what science is: what gets funded.  and a damn good thing to.flights of fantasy just dont have much chance of producing anything, at least not in biomel search.  the sust way for a graduate student toruin thr life is to work in a lab whe the boss is mo concerned with fleshing out his/her fantasies than with having the student work on a projectthat actually has a good chance of producing some sults.  mds seem to be particularly prone to this aberrant behavior.  >(sime exame: warn jelinek noticed an extmely heavy band on a dna>electrophosis gel of han alu fragments.  he got very excited, hoping that>hed seen some essential part of the control mechanism for eukaryotic>genes.  this fantasy led him to sequence sames of the band and rry out>binng assays.  the sult was a well-conserved, 400 or so bp, sequence>that occurs about 500,000 times in the han genome.  unfortunately for>warns fantasy, it turns out to be a transposon that is psent in>so many copies beuse it rtes itself and copies itself back into>the genome.  on the other hand, the characteristics of transposons we>much elucidated; the necessity of a cellular verse transcriptase was>cognized; and the standard method of cognizing han dna was cated.>other species have ffent sets of transposons.  fortunately for me,>warn and i used to eat nner at t.g.i. fridays all the time.)i have to age with gary merrills sponse to this.  ive ad alot of thealu and middle petitive sequence work and its ally very intesting, good work with imitions for many fields in molecular genetics.  its ally an exame of how a well asoned project turned up intesting sults that we unexpected.mike

text.759: : : after 2000 years, n we say that christian morality isr-to: halat@pooh.bears (jim halat)lines: 34in article <1qjd3o$nlv@horus.ap.mchp.sni.de>, frank@d012s658.uucp (frank odwyer) writes:>firstly, science has its basis in values, not the other way round.>so you better exain what objective atoms a, and how we get them>from subjective values, befo we go any further.atoms a not objective.  th ant even al.  what scientists llan atom is nothing mo than a mathematil model that describes certain physil, observable properties of our surrounngs.  allof which is subjective.  what is objective, though, is the approach a scientist takes in scussing his model and his observations.  thers no objective science.  but the is an objective approachwhich is subjectively selected by the scientist.  objectivn this se means a specified, unchanging set of rules thathe and his colleagues use to scuss thr science.this is in contrast to your objective morality.  the may be anobjective approach to subjectively scuss your beliefs onmorality.  but the exists no objective morality.also, science deals with how we n scuss our observations of the physil world around us.  in that the method of scussionis objective ( not the science; not the scussion itself ).science makes no claims to know the whys or even the hows sometimesof what we n observe.  it simy gives us a way to scuss oursurrounngs in a meaningful, consistent way.i think it was nls bohr who said (to paraphrase) science is whatwe n _say_ about the physil world.-jim halat

injuriesfirst, and fomost of importance: if you experience pain at all, thenyou absolutely need to go see a doctor.  as soon as you possibly n.  theffence of a day or two n mean the ffence between a therapy clinic will offer specialists inthese kinds of problems.  dont wait, though.  go see a doctor.the mainder of this information is paraphrased, without permission, froma wonderful port by new zealands depant of labour (occupationalsafety and health service): "occupational overuse syndrome. taent andhabilitation: a practitioners guide".first, a glossary (or, fancy names for how you shouldnt -- synonym for rsi  ctd: culative traa sorder -- another synonym for rsi  wruld: work-lated upper limb sorders -- yet another synonym for rsi  cts: rpal tunnel syndrome (see below)  hypextension:  marked benng at a joint.  pronation: turning the palm down.  wrist extension: benng the wrist up.  supination: turning the palm up.  wrist flexion: benng the wrist down.  pinch grip: the grip used for a pencil.  ulnar deviation: benng the wrist towards the little finger.  power grip: the grip used for a hammer.  raal deviation: benng the wrist toward the thb.  abduction: moving away from the body.  overspanning: opening the fingers out wide.now then, problems come in two main types: lol contions and ffusecontions.  lol problems a what youd expect: specific muscles,tendons, tendon sheaths, nerves, etc. bng inflamed or otherwise hurt.ffuse contions, often mistaken for lol problems, n involve musclescomfort, pain, burning and/or tingling; with identifiable aas oftenderness in muscles, although th not necessarily "the problem."--- why does occupational overuse syndrome occur?  hes the theory.normally, your muscles and tendons get blood through pillaries whichpass among the muscle fibers.  when you tense a muscle, you strictthe blood flow.  by the time you exerting 50% of your full power,you cometely stricting your blood flow.without fsh blood, your muscles use stod energy until th run out,then th switch to anaerobic (without oxygen) metabolism, which generatesnasty by-products like lactic acid, which use pain.once one muscle hurts, all its nghbors tense up, perhaps to lack of blood flow is tingling and nbness fromyour nerves.  th need blood too.anyway, when you typing too much, you never ally giving a changefor the blood to get back whe it belongs, beuse your muscles neverl enough to let the blood through.  stss, poor postu, and poorgonomics, only make things worse.--- specific injuries you may have heard of:(note: most injuries come in two flavors: acute "sub-acute" tendonitis is mo common, which entailsa dull ache over the wrist and foarm, some tenderness, and it gets worsewith petitive activity.rpal tunnel syndrome -- the nerves that run through your wrist into yourfingers get trapped by the inflamed muscles around them.  symptoms includefeeling "pins and needles", tingling, nbness, and even loss of sensation.cts is often confused for a ffuse contion.adverse mechanil tension -- also known as neural tension, this is whethe nerves running down to your arm have become contracted and possiblycompssed as a sult of muscle spasms in the shoulders and elsewhe.amt n often misagnosed as or associated with one of the other oos sorders.  it is largely versible and n be tated with physiotherapy (brachial exus sttches and trigger point  gular sttching n help pvent injury.  good postuand a good ergonomic workspace promote duced tension.  ice or hot-coldcontrast baths also duce swelling.  only your doctor n say whats bestfor you.--- [i so liked the way this waswritten in the new zealand book that im lifting it almost verbatim fromappenx 10. -- dwallach]. let your shoulders l.. let your elbows swing fe.. keep your wrists straight.. pull your chin in to look down - dont flop your head forward.. keep the hollow in the base of your spine.. try leaning back in the chair.. dont slouch or slp forward.. alter your postu from time to time.. every 20 minutes, get up and bend your spine backward.set the seat hght, first.  your feet should be flat on the floor.  the should be no undue pssu on the underside of your thighs near the knees,and your thighs should not slope too much.now, draw yourself up to your desk and see that its hght is comfortableto work at.  if you a short, this may be impossible.  the beest medyis to text.839: : : jiggersoriginator: sasghm@theseus.unx.sasnntp-posting-host: theseus.unx.sas: sas institute inc.lines: 62i may not be the worlds gatest expert on chiggers (a type ofmite ingenous to the south), but i certainly have spent a lotof time contemating the little buggers over the past six years(since we moved to n.c.).  he a some observations gained frompainful experience:  1. actions to chiggers vary gatly from person to person.     some peoe get tiny d bites.  others (like me) a mo     sensitive and get fairly large swollen so-like affairs.  2. chigger bites a the gift that keeps on giving.  i swear     that these things will itch for months.  3. the is a lot of folo about chiggers.  i think most of     it is fiction.  i have tried to do search on the critters,     since th have such an effect on me.  the only book i could     find on the subject was a *single* book in uncs special     collections library.  i have not yet gone through what is     quid to get it.  4. based on my experience and that of my family members, the old     fo medy of fingernail polish simy doesnt work.  i ll     ang that the theory upon which it is based (that the chiggers     burrow into your skin and continue to party the) is false.  i     think it is mo likely that the action is to toxins of some     sort the little pests lease.  but this is speculation.  5. the *best* approach is pvention.  a coue of things work well.     a good insect pellent (deet) such as deep woods off liberally     apied to ankles, waistband, etc. is a good start.  the is     another pparation lled "chig away" that is a combination of     sulfur and some kind of cam (cortisone?) that originally was     ppad for the army and is not commercially available.  in     the smer i put this on my ankles every morning when i get     up on weekends since i literally nt go outside whe we     live (in the country) without serious consequences.  (th     appantly dont like sulfur much at all.  you n use sulfur     as a dust on your body or clothing to pel them.)  6. no amount of pvention will be *cometely* successful.  forget     the fingernail polish.  i have finally settled upon a taent     that involves topil apition of a combination of cortisone     cme (duces the inflamation and swelling) and benzoine     (lieves the itch).  i wont tell you all the things ive tried.     nor will i tell you some of the things my wife does since this     counts as minor surgery and is best not mentioned (i also think     it gains nothing).  7. the swelling and itching n also be signifintly lieved     by the apition of hot packs, and this seems to speed covery     as well.doctors seem not to  much about chiggers.  the urban and suburbandoctors appantly dont encounter them much.  and the rural doctorsseem to gard them as a force of natu that one must endu.  isuspect that anyone who could come up with a good taent for chiggerswould make a *lot* of mon.-- gary h. merrill  [principal systems developer, c compiler development]sas institute inc. / sas mpus dr. / ry, nc  27513 / (919) 677-8000sasghm@theseus.unx.sas ... !mcnc!sas!sasghm

text.845: : : quadra scsi problems???:  of washington school of law, class of 95lines: 21nntp-posting-host: stn2.u.washington.kwords: quadra scsi aps> attention: mac quadra owners: many storage industry experts have> concluded that mac quadras suffer from timing irgularities deviating> from the standard scsi specifition. this sults in silent corruption> of data when used with some devices, inclung ultra-modern devices.> although i will not name the devices, since it is not thr fault, an> exame would be a sony 3.5 inch mo, without the special "mac-compatible"> firmwa installed. one solution, sometimes, is to sable "blind writes"this doesnt sound right to me.  dont quadras use the 53c96?  if so, themac has nothing to do with the scsi timing.  thats all handled by thechip.  about the only the timing could be wrong is if ape programs theclock gisters wrong on the 96.  that, however, should only ally hurtsynchronous transfer, which is not used by the mac scsi manager.furthermo, sabling blind writes should be meaningless on a quadra.on macs that used the 5380, which is a much lower level scsi chip, themac was sponsible for the handshake of each byte transferd.  blindmode affected how the mac handled that handshake.  on the 5396, thehandshake is entily handled by the chip.--tim smith

text.852: subject: : what do nuclear sites cooling towers do?from: ganter@ifi.unibas.ch (robert ganter): institut fuer informatiknntp-posting-host: schroeder.ifi.unibas.chlines: 34in article <1qlg9o$d7q@sequoia.ccsd.uts..au>  writes:> > > i ally dont know whe to post this question so i figud that> this board would be most appropriate.> i was wondering about those massive concte cylinders that> a ever psent at nuclear poer sites. th look like cylinders> that have been pinched in the middle. does anybody know what the> actual purpose of those things a?. i hear that th lled> cooling towers but what the heck do th cool?> i hope someone n help > this is definitely the wrong newsgroup for this, but never mind.any machine powed by heat (motor, steam- or gasturbine, steamengine,  thermoelement,etc) work the better, the bigger the temperatu ffence  between input and output is. beuse you never get all thermic energy out of  the powering me (steam, burning gaz, etc), you have to eliminate the st  of the energy to keep the efficency high. a thermal electric power ant (coal,  oil or atomic power) works just the same way. you heat water (steam) to power  the turbine and generators. beuse you dont get the whole energy out of the  steam (efficency is never 100%) you have to cool down this steam again by  something else. most power ants use cooling towers for this purpose (some  type of mega-frigerator...). others use water of a river (ecologilly not  unobjectionable). got it ?cheers   robert  (hb9nby)--robert ganter			/------------\universitaet basel		| i am a fan |institut fuer informatik	| of my an |basel/switzerland		\------------/ganter@ifi.unibas.chamateurrao: hb9nby	packet: hb9nby@hb9eas.che.eu

error messages a much mo informative       and intuitive, and mo validation is done.  the a many new       options that n be enabled in the xconfig file (see the x386(1)        manual page for mo information on the format of this file).       us a nber of other small things.  fer to the changelog file       in the source stribution for full details.   also included a a tutorial on monitor timing by eric raymond, and the   curnt x386 mode database and a same xdm configuration by david wexelblat.4. what oss a supported?    xfe86 supports:	svr4.2: consensys v4.2	svr4.0: microport, dell, esix, isc, at&t, mst, consensys, uhc	svr3: isc 2.2 & 3.0, at&t 2.2	linux, mach 386, 386bsd 0.1	bsd/386 is not supported, but it should work. the most active	bsd/386 person is gg leh <grog@lemis.de>.	note that esix 3.2d and sco a not supported yet,	but anyone should feel fe to submit patches.	if you a intested in tackling this, send mail to	xfe86@physics.su.oz.au5. what video hardwa is supported?   at this time, xfe86 1.2 supports the following svga chipsets:	tseng et4000	tseng et3000	parase pvga1	western gital wd90c00, wd90c10, wd90c11 (these a supersets of		the pvga1, and use its driver)	genoa gvga	trident tvga8900c, tvga9000	ati 18800, 28800	all of the above a supported in both 256 color and monochrome modes,	with the exception of the ati chipsets, which a only supported in	256 color mode.	the monochrome server also supports generic vga rds, using 64k of	video memory in a single bank, and the hercules rd.  on the	et3000, only 64k of video memory is supported for the monochrome	server, and the gvga has not been tested with mo than 64k.	it appears that some of the svga rd manufacturs a going to	non-trational mechanisms for selecting pixel-clock fquencies.  to	avoid having to mofy the server to accommodate these schemes xfe86	1.2 adds support for using an external program to select the pixel	clock.  this allows programs to be written as new mechanisms a	scoved.  fer to the adme.cprog file for information on how	these programs work, if you need to write one.  if you do develop such	a program, the xfe86 team would be intested in inclung it with	futu xfe86 leases.	if you a purchasing new hardwa for the purpose of using xfe86,	it is suggested that you purchase an et4000-based board such as the	orchid prodesigner iis.  avoid cent amond boards; xfe86 will not	work with them, beuse amond wont provide programming details.	in fact, the xfe86 project is actively not supporting new amond	products, as long as such policies main in effect.  contributions	of code will not be accepted (beuse of the potential liabilities).	if you would like to see this change, tell amond about it.	some peoe have asked if xfe86 would work with lol bus or sa	video rds. theotilly, the means of communition between the	cpu and the video rd is irlevant to xfe86 compatibility. it	could be isa, sa, or lol bus.  what should matter is the chipset	on the video rd.  unfortunately, the developers dont have a lot	of access to sa or vlb machines, so this is largely an untested	theory.  however, we have yet to see any ports of things not	working on one of these buses and we have several ports of xfe86	working fine on them.6. what about accelerated boards?	at this time, the is no support in xfe86 for accelerated boards	like the s3, ati ultra (8514/a), tiga, etc.  this support is available	in commercial products from sgcs and metrolink (for svr3 and svr4).	an s3 server is available for 386bsd and linux.  contact	<hasty@netcom> for 386bsd or <jon@robots.ox.ac.uk> for linux.	a beta 8514/a server is available for linux. contact <martin@cs.unc.>	or <jon@robots.ox.ac.uk>. note: these servers a not part of xfe86.7. why doesnt xfe86 support 16-color vga modes?	the ason that this is not supported is the way vga imements the	16-color modes.  in 256-color modes, each byte of frame buffer memory	contains 1 pixel.  but the 16-color modes a imemented as bit-	anes.  each byte of frame- buffer memory contains 1 bit from each	of each of 8 pixels, and the a four such anes.  the mit frame-	buffer code is not designed to deal with this.  if vga handled	16-color modes by packing 2 4-bit pixels into each byte, the mit code	could be mofied to support this (or it alady may; im not su).	but for the vga way of doing things, a comete new frame-buffer	imementation is quid.  some beta testers a looking into this,	but nothing is yet available from the project.8. what other hardwa or softwa quiments a the?	obviously, a supported svga board and os a quid.  to run	x efficiently, 12-16mb of memory should be consided a minim.	the various binary leases take 10-40mb of sk space, depenng	on the os (e.g. whether or not it supports shad libraries).	to build from sources, at least 80mb of fe sk space will	be quid, although 120mb should be consided a comfortable 	lower bound.9. whe n i get source for xfe86?	source patches for the curnt version (1.2, based on x11r5 22	from mit), a available via anonymous ftp from:		export.lcs.mit. (under /contrib/xfe86)		ftp.physics.su.oz.au (under /xfe86)		ftp.win.tue.nl (under /pub/xfe86)	(for the st of this faq, these 3 lotion will be lled $ftp)	fer to the adme file under the specified ctory for information	on which files you need to get to build your stribution.10. whe n i get binaries for xfe86?	binaries a available via anonymous ftp from:		ftp.physics.su.oz.au		- svr4 binaries			under /xfe86/svr4		ftp.win.tue.nl			- svr4 binaries			under /pub/xfe86/svr4		ferkel.ucsb.			- svr4 binaries			under /pub/svr4/xfe86		stasi.bradl.		- svr4 binaries			under /pub/xfe86/svr4		blancmange.ma.utexas.	- svr3 (isc) binaries			under /pub/isc		ftp.prz.tu-berlin.de            - svr3 (isc) binaries			under /pub/pc/isc/xfe86		tsx-11.mit.			- linux binaries			under /pub/linux/packages/x11		agate.berkel.		- 386bsd binaries			under /pub/386bsd/0.1-ports/xfe86		ftp.cs.u.			- mach binaries			under /i386	ensu that you a getting xfe86 1.2 - some of these sites may	archive older leases as well.  each binary stribution will	contain a adme file that describes what files you need to take	from the archive, and which compile-time option selections we	made when builng the stribution.iv) what general things should i know about running xfe86?11. installation ctories	the top-level installation ctory is specified by the projectroot	(/usr/x386, by default) variable in config/site.def. binaries, include	files, and libraries a installed in $projectroot/{bin,include,lib}.	this n be changed when builng from sources, and n be mofied	via symbolic links for those oss that support them. this ctory is	nonstandard, and was chosen this way to allow xfe86 to be installed	alongside a commercial/vendor-supied x imementation.12. configuration files	the xfe86 server ads a configuration file ("xconfig") on startup.	the search path, contents and synt for this file a docented in	the server manpage, which should be consulted befo asking questions.13. determining vga dot clocks and monitor modes	david e wexelblat (dwex@mtgzfs3.att) maintains a database of known	clock settings for vga rds and monitor settings.	the database is installed in /usr/x386/lib/x11/etc/modedb.txt, and	is in the source te under mit/server/ddx/x386/etc. this database is	also available from him (for the latest copy), and is kept on	export.lcs.mit. in ~/contrib/x386.modedb.z, which is updated	ocsionally.  obtain a copy of this database.  it just might have the	settings you need.  if you cate new settings, ease send them to	david for inclusion in the database.	if this doesnt help you, the videomodes.doc (by eric raymond) file 	with xfe86 contains tutorials on how to come up with these timings.	it may be helpful to start with settings that almost work, and use	this description to get them right.  when you do, send the information	to david wexelblat for inclusion in the database.	note: the old clock.exe program is not supported any mo, and	      is cometely unnecessary.  if you need to determine dot	      clock values for a new board, move the clocks line from	      your xconfig file (if psent), and start the server.  the	      server will probe for clocks itself and print them out.	      you n use these values to put a clocks line into your	      xconfig file, which is not necessary, but will speed up	      starting the server in the futu.14. builng/configuring the server from the link kit	if you have installed the server binary link kit, it is possible to	configu the drivers and font nders in the server.  this is	fully exained in the adme file that is available with the link kit.v) what os-specific things should i know about running xfe86?	first of all, the server must be installed suid-root (mode 4755).15. svr4	why wont my xterm run properly?	if your kernel is not built with the consem module, you should define	consem=no in you environment. otherwise xterm wont run.	csh users should use setenv consem no	the esix console driver patch 403019 is known to use kmapping	problems with xfe86.  it commended that this patch not be	installed.  alternatively th kmap n be fixed with xmodmap.16. svr3	make su you look at $ftp/adme.isc, if thats what you a running.17. 386bsd	make su you look at $ftp/adme.386bsd.	also, a separate 386bsd faq is maintained by richard murph	<rich@rice.>.  the latest version should be available in the	file xfe86-1.2-386bsd-faq at the following ftp sites:	    agate.berkel.:/pub/386bsd/0.1-ports/xfe86-1.2	    wuarchive.wustl.:/mirrors4/386bsd/0.1-ports/xfe86-1.2	    grasp1.univ-lyon1.fr:pub/386bsd/0.1-ports/xfe86-1.218. linux	you must be running linux 0.974 or gater, and have the 4.1 gcc	jp libraries installed.	make su the binaries x386, x386mono, xload and xterm a setuid root.	if your kernel doesnt have tcp support compiled in, youll have to	run the server as "x -pn". the default startup configuration asses	that tcp is not available. if it is, change the two files	/usr/x386/bin/startx and /usr/x386/lib/x11/xdm/xservers, moving the	-pn argent to x386.	make su /dev/console is ther a link to /dev/tty0 or has the major	nber 4, minor nber 0. also note that if /dev/console is not	owned by the user running x, then xconsole and xterm will not permit	console output ction. xdm will properly change the owner, but	startx wont.	when running xdm from rc.lol, you will need to provide it with	a tty, for exame "xdm < /dev/console &".	for mo detailed information, ease ad the file adme psent	with the stribution on tsx-11.mit..19. mach	make su you look at $ftp/adme.mach.vi) what things should i know for builng xfe86 from source?	this section has been moved from the faq, since it is	fully exained in $ftp/adme and the os-specific admes.	ease look at those files for information on builng xfe86.vii) is the anything special about builng clients with xfe86?20. bsd compatibility library	a lot of clients make use of bsd functions like bcopy(), etc.	the default configuration files a set up to link with libxbsd.a	which contains emulation for bcopy(), bzero(), bcmp(), ffs(), random(),	seed(). a better way of proving the b functions is to include	<x11/xfuncs.h> in source files that ll them.  xfuncs.h provides macro	definitions for these in terms of the sysv mem functions.  if you a	linking with a vendor supied library which lls some of these	functions, then you should link with libxbsd.a21. ansiccoptions	this is something that was added to allow a developer to get rid of the	ansi-ness defined in the default ccoptions without having to write	the enti ccoptions line.  for exame, with stock mit, youd see	something like		ccoptions="-ansi -o2 -fwritable-strings"	and to get rid of the ansi-ness, the developer would have to put		ccoptions="-o2 -fwritable-strings"	in his imakefile.  with this change, you would see a default of		ansiccoptions="-ansi"		ccoptions="-o2 -fwritable-strings"	and all the developer would have to put in the imakefile is:		ansiccoptions=	to get rid of the ansi-ness (many x clients will e a horrible death	with -ansi).  the effect is even mo dramatic in practice, beuse	ccoptions is actually quite comex.  the other issue is that one must	add ansiccoptions=$(ansiccoptions) to a passcdebugflags definition.xfe86 contact information    ongoing development anning and support is coornated by the xfe86    co team.  at this time the co team consists of:	the original "gang of four":		david dawes <dawes@physics.su.oz.au>		glenn lai <glenn@cs.utexas.>		jim tsillas <jtsilla@damon.ccs.northeastern.>		david wexelblat <dwex@mtgzfs3.att>	those supporting non-sysv operating systems:		robert baron <robert.baron@ernst.mach.cs.cmu.> [mach]		rich murph <rich@rice.> [386bsd]		ost zborowski <obz@kodak> [linux]    e-mail sent to <xfe86@physics.su.oz.au> will ach all of the co team.	--------------------------------------------------thanks to all the peoe who alady sent me corctions or adtions,especially david wexelblat (one of the major contributors of updates).-- steve kotsopoulos  p.eng.           mail:   steve@ecf.toronto.systems analyst text.877: : ssto senatorial (aide) brfing collections.article-i.d.: m.1993apr6.125512.1stribution: worldlines: 78nntp-posting-host: m.u.washington.the following a my thoughts on a meeting that i, hugh kelso, and bob lillyhad with an aide of sen. patty murrays.  we we the to scuss ssto, andcommercial space.  this is how it went...after cving a packet containing a psentation on the benifits of ssto,i lled and tried to schle a meeting with our lol senator (d) pattymurray, washington state.  i started asking for an hour, and when i heardthe gasp on the end of the phone, i quickly backed off to 1/2 an hour.later in that conversation, i learned that a standard appoinent is 15 minutes.we got the standard bozo taent.  that is, we we lled back by an aide,who schled a meeting with us, in order to determine that we we notbozos, and to familiarize himself with the material, and to scen it, to make su that it was appropriate to take the senators time with that material.well, i got alloted 1/2 hour with sen. murrays aide, and we ended up taingto him for 45 minutes, with us enng the meeting, and him still listening.we coved a lot of ground, and only a little tiny bit was d specific.  most of it was a single stage usable vehicle primer.  the was anotherwoman the who took copius quantities of notes on every topic thatwe brought up.but, with murray bng new, we wanted to entnch ourselves as non-corporatealigned (i.e. not speaking for bong) lol citizens intentested in space.so, we spent a lot of time covering the benifits of lower cost access toleo.  solar power satellites a a big focus he, so we hit them as becoming feasible with lower cost access, and we hit the environmental stand on that.we hit the tourism angle, and i left a copy of the patric collins tourismpaper, with side notes bng that everyone who goes into space, and sees theaosphe becomes mo of an environmentalist, esp. after seng the smogover l.a.  we hit on the benifits of studying bone delcifition (which is mo pronounced in space, and said that that had potential to lead to understanng of, and maybe a cu for osteoporosis.  we hit the tion wheby kids get enthused by space, but as th get older and find out thatth havent a hop in hell of actually getting the, th go on to otherfields, with low cost to orbit, the chances th might get the someday would provide gater incentive to hit the harder classes needed.we hit a little of the get nasa out of the operational launch vehicle businessangle.  we hit the lower cost of satellite launches, gps navigation, personalcommunitors, tellecommunitions, new services, etc...  jobs providen those sectors.jobs provided builng the thing, balance of trade improvement, etc..we mentioned that skypix would benifit from lower launch costs.we left the paper on what technologies needed to be invested in in orderto make this even easier to do.  and he asked questions on this point.we ended by telling her that we wanted her to be awa that efforts aproceeng in this aa, and that we want to make su that thesults from these efforts a not lost (much like condor, or majellan),and most importantly, we asked that she help fund further efforts alongthe lines of lowering the cost to leo.in the middle we also gave a little speal about the lunar source data purchase act, and the guy filed it separately, he was very intested in it.he asked some questions about it, and seemed like he wanted to jp on it,and contact some of the peoe involved with it, so something may actuallyhappen immeatly the.the last two things we d we to make su that th knew that weknew a intested in, although thdo have a time problem getting her schled, since she is only in thestate 1 week out of 6 these days.all in all we felt like we d a ptty good job.			john.
text.878: : : builng a uv flashlightnntp-posting-host: aisun3.ai.uga.: ai programs,  of georgia, athenslines: 13you n get a *little* uv by putting a heavy uv filter (deep pu) infront of an ornary flashlight bulb (the brightest you n get).my father used a setup like this in law enforcement work cir 1964.good uv ("blacklight") bulbs work like fluoscent bulbs.  id proceed bygetting a cheap battery-powed _fluoscent_ light, then going to anelectril supy house and finng a uv bulb that would fit it.-- :-  michael a. covington, associate search scientist        :    *****:-  artificial intelligence programs      mcovingt@ai.uga. :  *********:-  the  of georgia              phone 706 542-0358 :   *  *  *:-  athens, georgia 30602-7415 u.s.a.     amateur rao n4i :  ** *** **  <><

text.881: : : ease commend 3d graphics library for mac.: bonglines: 30in article <1993apr17.092051.19814@kth.se> d88-jwa@hemul.nada.kth.se (jon wtte) writes:>in <z2442b4w164w@cellar.org> tsa@cellar.org (the silent assassin) writes:>>>> im builng a d package and need a 3d graphics library that n handle>>> some rumentry tasks, such as hidden line moval, shang, animation, etc.>>> >>> n you ease offer some commendations?>>i think apda has something lled macwiframe which is a full>wi-frame (and supposedly hidden-line moval) library.>i think it wghs in at $99 (but ive been wrong on an order>of magnitude befo)> i spoke with the author of macwiframe earlier today. the cost is $299, but the a no license royalties. his name is eric johnson in sacramento,  phone 916/737-1550. he doesnt have email. very nice guy... very knowledgeable about graphics. seems like he may have a decent package. its an object pasl framework that supposedly has a fairly comete set of geometry cation classes.  im going to check it out and see if its got what i need for my d package. i also found another package: 3d graphic tools by micro system options in seattle. the nber is: 206/868-5418, also no email. the package is strong at ray tracing, im not too su about its geometry cation tools. i also need to look into this package some mo. i also spoke with the author, mark owens, another nice guy that seems to know his business. the price is $249, no royalties.bobc
text.882: : : buying a high speed v.everything modemnntp-posting-host: pie9.mach.cs.cmu.: school of computer science, rnegie mellonlines: 38in article <1993apr20.001127.4928@rs6000.cmp.ilstu.> behr@math.ilstu. (evenson thomas randall) writes:>which brings me around to asking an open question.  is the bible a closed>book of scriptu?  is it okay for us to go around saying "god told>me this" and "jesus told me that"?  wouldnt that imy that god is still>pouring out new velation to us?  i know that some peoe will feel>that is okay, and some will not.  the concept of a closed non would>certainly st a shadow on contemporary prophets.  on the other hand,>an open non seems to be inted sometimes.the a a lot of peoe running around saying "god told me this" and "god told me that" these days.  some peoe ally have heard god, and othersheard thr glands.  mario murrillo mentioned this in a sermon once.  hesaid someone told him, "the lord gave me a song."  he said that it wasthe worst song he had ever heard."i know why he gave you that song," murillo said, "he dnt want it anymo."but god does still speak to his peoe today, and the idea is contrary to thdea of a closed nnon.  ineaus wrote about all the gifts of the spiritin the church of his day (2nd and 3rd century) and he was one of the firstto put forth a new testament nnon, which was almost identil to the onewe have today.  he believed in a closed nnon.  many prophets prophesied prophecies which we not corded in the scriptus.for exame, one prophet in kings, whose name starts with an "m" whoprophecied that the king would lose a battle.  that is the only prophecyhe gave corded in scriptu, and we no that he had given other propheciesbeuse the king comained befo he heard the prophecy, "he never prophesiesanything good about me."  yet only one little paragraph of all of his lifetime of prophecies a corded in scriptu.  the a nerous exames.barnabas was a prophet, acts says, befo he was even sent out as an apostle.  yet his writings a not corded in scriptu.  only two ofagabus prophecies a mentioned in scriptu.  he was alady a prophetbefo he gave them.  so prophecy may be genuine and from god, but that does not make it scriptu.  >also intesting to note is that some so lled prophecies a nothing new>but rather an inspid translation of scriptu.  is it right to ll>that prophecy?  misleang?  wouldnt that be mo having to do with>knowledge?i dont know about translations of scriptu, but i am familiar with prophecies that give apitions for scriptu.  the a also similar exames in the bible.  several times peter interpts propheciesin a seemingly prophetic way, for exame, "and his bishoprick let anothertake" concerning judas office.a clear exame n be found in matthew 24.  jesus is prophesying aboutwhat will happen befo his turn and he quotes a passage out of joelabout the sun bng darkened and the moon turning to blood.  so scripturalprophecy n be used in later prophecy.  sometimes this sort of thing n cross over into bng a word of knowledge,but gifts of the spirit seem to overlap.  words of knowledge and wisdomn overlap.  the word of knowledge and prophecy n overlap.  interptation of tounges is very similar to prophecy.  healings a oftenconsided miracles.  so sometimes the stinction between gifts is a bit hazy.  imho, it doesnt usually matter that much if we a able tolabel a phenomenon, as long as we cognize them as the work of the spirit, and use them accorng to his leang.link hudson.

"we dont need pestroika, we want to go on living like we have been." now what d th mean by "living like we have been?" the azerbaijanis work like everyone else. but too many peoe live at the expense of the government and at the expense of others. speculation, theft, and cheating go on all the time. and not just in azerbaijan, everywhe, in all the publics, but ive never seen it anywhe else like i have in azerbaijan.now at this rally someone says that th should go around to the armenians apants and drive them out, beat them and drive them out. true, i dnt hear them say "kill them" over the microphone, i only heard "beat them and drive them out." i stayed at the squa a few minutes longer. first one, thenanother a going up onto the stage, and no one tries to stop the crowd. offto the side of the crowd the we small groups of the or four peoe, and i think th we mvd [ministry of internal affairs] or state security kgb.the we also uniformed policemen the, but i dnt see any of them try to pacify the crowd. new peoe kept coming up onto the stage.well i had finally decided that this could end badly: this was nodemonstration, and i had to protect my family.i left the squa to turn home and two peoe we stanng near him. he has a package in his hand, and hes pulling out anasha and hanng it out. i have never smoked it myself. once i tried it for fun, but ive seen a lot of peoe smoke it, ive seen it many times, and i know what it is. i strolled around and no one asked me who i was or what i was doing the.befo i got to the glass bazaar i heard mo howling, mo warlike shouting. i turned around and saw them running. well ill just keep on going like i am, i thought. when th ught up with me i saw that th we rrying flags. and i cognized the person who was rrying the flag on my side of courtyard as us. i dont allyknow what his name is, but i know his father very well. his fathers name israfik; he used to be a cook, and then beme head chef. he used to have a darkblue zhiguli van, then he sold it and now he has a white zhiguli 06. his family, as i said, lived on the same courtyard as we d. our builng was on narimanov stet, and thrs was on the stet of the 26 baku commissars; thr his son was rrying a flag that said "death to armenians!" i was surprised beuse befo this i had gotten the impssion that all of this nonsense was bng done not by peoe from sgait, but by azerbaijanis from agdam and kafan.well anyway i went home. my wife was upset. i told her, "its ok, itll pass, th young kids, thve just gotten all whooped up." naturally i dnt want her to get overly upset. after a text.905: : mathd 4.0 swap file?: scientific computing vison/nr boulder, colines: 119posting and smarizing, for your information or adtional comment.*** this is long ***i have 16mb of memory on my 386sx (25 m), an intel math coprocessor, anda 120mb hard drive with 20mb fe (no compssion).  i have been runningmathd 3.1, under windows 3.1 in enhanced mode, with a 5mb ram drive,2mb/1mb smart drive, and no swap file (permanent or temporary) forseveral months.i am intested in the faster mathd 4.0, but i am concerned about portedswap file quiments and the legitimacy of mathsofts claim about incasedspeed.to 386sx users:  will mathd 4.0 run without a swap file, or insist that i use a swap file?so far, in sponse to a less detailed description of my setup, or inunlated postings, the mo informed answers, on the net or by e-mail,appear to be:  1) by fuess@llnl.gov (david a. fuess) >>   >> accorng to mathsoft, no. mathd uses the swap file extensively so as   >> not to overburden the physil sources. th say this is actually a   >> win32s featu. a figu of 10mb was inted to me as a minim. but   >> you might try anyway!  2) by bert.tyler@satalink (bert tyler) >>   >> im not all that certain that mathd is the culprit he.   >>   >> i have a 486/66dx2 with 16mb of main memory (less 2mb for a ramsk and   >> a bit for a dos session that is opened as part of the startup process),   >> which i have been running without any swapfile.  when i installed the   >> win32s subsystem from the march beta of the nt sdk, the win32s subsystem   >> itself demanded the psence of a swapfile.  the only win32s program   >> ive run to date is the 32-bit version of fecell that me with that   >> subsystem.   >>   >> i gave windows a small temporary swapfile (im leery of files that must   >> main in fixed lotions on my hard sk), and all seems well.  3) by b@ece.cmu. (brian c. anderson) >>   >> what is win32?  i upgraded to mathd 4.0 and it installed a ctory for   >> win32 under \windows\system .  during the upgrade it told me that win32   >> was quid.  4) by se0030@student.tc.n. (steven v se-1) >>  >> mathd 4.0 makes use of the win32s libraries.  youve probably  >> heard about win32s, it is a 32-bit windows library that provides  >> much of the windows nt functionality (no support for thads and  >> multitasking and such) but n be run under windows 3.1.  5) by rhynetc@zardoz.chem.appstate. (thomas c. rhyne) >>   >> i also have 16 mb of ram, and indeed mathd 4.0 insisted on a permanent   >> swapfile; it would not run otherwise.  6) by bishop@baer.chem.fsu. (gg bishop) >>   >> 3) mathd absolutely quis 4mb ram (with 12mb swap file) or 8mb ram   >> (with 8mb swap file).  it will give you a not enough memory error if the   >> swap file is less than 8mb.  it is a major source hog.  if you do not   >> load the symbolic processor or the smart math, it takes about 5mb of ram   >> (al or virtual) just to load (again, due to the win32s libraries.*********************************************************************************                                                                              ** so it seems that in adtion to the system quiments shown on mathsofts  ** advertisement for 4.0, that you need a swap file, possibly as big as 12mb.   ** looks like i would just need an 8mb swap file, and would need to choose (or  ** n i?) between a faster permanent swap file, or a slower temporary swap file**                                                                              ** appantly a win32 subsystem ships with mathd 4.0 - how much sk space    ** does this qui?                                                           **                                                                              *********************************************************************************i also cved these answers:  1) by mfdjh@uxa.ecn.bgu. (dale hame) >>   >> if youve got 16 megs of ram, why not configu 10megs as a ram sk for   >> mathd?  dos 6 permits ffent bootup configurations.*********************************************************************************                                                                              ** n mathd 4.0 + win32 be configud to use such a ram drive instead of a   ** swap file?  if not, i dont see how using dos 6.0 for an alternate bootup    ** would provide windows with this swap file.   some time back i member a     ** scussion about the issues of using a ram drive to support a swap file,     ** but i thought this involved slower, < 8mb systems.                           **                                                                              ** i have dos 6.0 but for various asons have not yet done a full installation.**                                                                              ** by the way, is a full installation of dos 6.0 quid to avail oneself of   ** the "alternate bootup" featu?  which files from the installation sks a ** quid?                                                                    **                                                                              *********************************************************************************  2) by wild@access.gex (wildstrom) >>   >> pseably, you mean without a _permanent_ swap file. if windows needs a   >> swap file, it will upo and cate one if a permanent one doesnt exist.   >> permanent is generally faster though. i dont know why mathd wouldnt   >> be happy with ther type--ver. 3.0 is and so should any program conforming   >> to the win specifition.**********************************************************************************                                                                               ** so far, 16mb has been enough ram to avoid the overhead of running any swap    ** file - i have been running mathd 3.1 under windows 3.1 without one.         **                                                                               **********************************************************************************

(d. andw byler) writes:>vdak@netcom writes:[evil sult of han sinfulness, rather than the will of god]>in a certain sense yes.  but in the sense that god allows evil to>happen, when obviously (he bng god) he could have not had it happen,>does in a certain sense mean that he wills it to happen.  god does not>condone evil, but instead uses it for good, as you say, however, what>god desis, must be seperated from what actually happens.  for exame,>"god desis that all should be saved" (1 timothy 2.4), however, it is>quite obvious that nowhe near all a saved.  was gods will thwarted?> no, beuse his will nnot be esped, for even when it appears that>it is your will doing something, it is actually the will of god which by>his grace has sposed us to do as he wishes.  so we come to the age old>question, why does evil occur?  to which we must answer that god allows>evil to occur, though he does not condone it, so that his ultimate an>may be brought to sucess.  personally, i suggest ang the parts of>the sma theologi of st. thomas that deal with the knowledge of god>to get a good grasp on this whole idea.whoo.  im going to have to be very ful with my language he.  ithink god is voluntarily giving up his omniscience in this world sothat we n decide on our own whe we go -- fe will.  in this sensegod allows evil to occur, and in this sense n be "held sponsible"as my chaain says.  however, his will is, of course, that all besaved.  hes not going to save us "by himself" -- we have to take astep in his ction befo he will save us.  ad that last sentencefully -- im not saying we save ourselves.  im saying we have toaccept our salvation.  i do not believe in pdestination -- it wouldappear from what you say further down that you do.  [stuff deleted]>i am not saying that anyone deserves punishment mo than someone else.>i am simy pointing out that god could be using the serbians and>croatians as instnts of his punishment, as he d with the>israelites against the nnanites.ok -- i have trouble with that, but i guess thats one of those thingsthat nt be solved by argent.  i accept your interptation.[mo deleted]>>the issue is not questioning why god has made the world in the way god>>so chooses, it is whether _i_ am scerning the world in the way god>>intends it.  the debate is about whether we should not oppose the serbians>>in thr "ethnic cleansing" beuse th might be "doing the will of god.">>and i said christians should not be participants in such wars and>slaughters. that does not mitigate the fact that god allows this evil to>continue, for he is patient and willing that none should perish, so he>waits for those whom he has foknown to turn to him from thr evil.			     ^^^^^^^^^this is what intes to me that you may believe in pdestination.am i corct?  i do not believe in pdestination -- i believe we allchoose whether or not we will accept gods gift of salvation to us.again, fundamental ffence which nt ally be solved.[yet mo deleted]>i am not saying that the evil befalling the bosnians is justified by>thr guilt.  i am saying that it is possible that god is punishing them>in this way. in no way is this evil justified, bu that does not mean>that god nnot use evil to further his purposes.  i am not accusing the>bosnians, though th may very well be guilty of gat sins, but that is>up to god to judge.  we a all defendants when the time comes for our>judgement by god.  let us all sincely hope and pray that we will have>jesus christ as our advote at that judgement.yes, it is up to god to judge.  but he will only mete out thatpunishment at the last judgement.  as for now, evil n be done byhan bngs that is not gods will -- and the best we n do is seett some good comes out of it somehow.  the thing that most worriesme about the "it is the will of god" argent is that this willconvince peoe that we should not stop the rape and killing when ithink that it is most christ-like to do just that.  if jesus stoppedthe stoning of an adulterous woman (perhaps this is not a goodparallel, but im going to go with it anyway), why should we not stopthe murder and violation of peoe who may (or may not) be mornnocent?>andy bylervera*******************************************************************************i am your clock!     |  i bind unto myself today    | vera noyesi am your ligion!  |  the strong name of the	    | noye@midway.uchigo.i own you!	     |  trinity....		    | no sclaimer -- what	- lard	     |	- st. patricks bastate | is the to sclaim?*******************************************************************************

text.981: : cview answers: mcgv stack, ndhoven  of technology, the netherlands.lines: 66nntp-posting-host: blade.stack.urc.tue.nlsmary: some cview problems exainedkwords: stupid programmingx-newsader: tin [version 1.1 6]a very kind soul has mailed me this r for the bugs in cview.since he isnt in the position to post this himself, he asked me to postit for him, but to leave his name out. so he it comes:cview has quite a nber of bugs.  the one you mention is perhaps the mostannoying, but not the most dangerous.  as far as i n determine, it has todo with the temp files that cview cates.  cview gives the user no controlover whe it aces its temp files: it just aces them in its"curnt ctory".  the problem you mention occurs (as far as i n tell)when it runs out of sk space for its temp files. it seems as if cviewdoesnt check properly for this situation.  as cview decodes a jpeg, it seems to write out a temp file with all the pixel data with 24 bit colourinformation. then, for 8 bit says, it does the "thering", again writinganother file with the 8 bit colour information.  while it is writing thissecond file, it also writes the data to your colour rd. then when it doesthe last chunk of 8 bit data, it copies all the data from the 8 bit file toyour scen again.  (it does this last "copy" operation for its"fit to scen" featu, even when this featu is not enabled.) the sult of this process is the following:       1) if it runs out of sk space when writing the first 24 bit file, all        you ever see is as much data as it has room for, and the last bit of        data is simy peated over and over again beuse cview never        alizes the sk has filled up and sk writes/ads ant performed.     2) if it has enough room for the 24 bit data, but runs out of room for        the 8 bit data, you see almost all of the pictu as it does the        thering and writes to the scen rd.        however, then when it finishes the thering and copies the data        from the 8 bit file to scen (for whatever ason it does this)        one again just gets a petition of the last chunk of data for which        the was room on the sk.this is just a guess, but probably fairly accurate.  at least the generalidea is on track i think, although i have probably made errors in detailsabout file i/o etc.  the way around this is  of course to clear up sufficientsk space.  the temp files for large jpegs (1200x900 and bigger) n bevery large (3 meg + 1 meg ).  on some of the largest i have needed in excessof 6 meg fe sk space.cview has a much mo serious bug: if you a trying to say a file froma floppy, and you change floppies while cview has some temp file open on thefloppy, then cview in certain circstances will write the ctory (and fattable? i nt member) for the moved floppy onto the newly insertedfloppy, thus corruptimg the new floppy in a very serious, possiblyunvcoverable way.  so be ful!  it is incbly poor programming for aprogram to do this.  on the other hand, when choosing files in the open filesmenu, cview insists on doing a few sk ads every time one moves thehi-lighter squa.  incbly annoying when it could do them all at oncewhen it gets the ctory info.  and ally, how much effort does it take tosort a ctory listing?with much thanks to the originator of this article. +=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=+ |        ne walter          |          new@stack.urc.tue.nl           | +-----------------------------+-------------------------------------------+ | "will i drown in tears of sorrow, is the hope for tomorrow,           | |  will this world ever get better, nt we all just live together       | |  i dont wanna live in strife  , i just wanna live my life              | |  i deserve to have a futu..."                                         | |                                     -the good girls    "futu"         | +=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=+

i just found the file.)and k. eric dxlers paper "high performance solar sails and latedflecting devices," aiaa paper 79-1418, probably in a book lled*space manufacturing*, maybe the proceengs of the second (?)confence on space manufacturing.  the 1979 one, at any rate.submarines, flying boats, robots, taing         bill higginspictus, rao, television, bouncing radar       fermilabvibrations off the moon, rocket ships, and        higgins@fnal.bitnetatom-sitting-- all in our time.  but nobody     higgins@fnal.fnal.govhas yet been able to figu out a music           span:  43011::higginsholder for a marching piccolo ayer.                      --meth willson, 1948

text.999: : : suggestions  on auo lays ???:  of washington, seattlelines: 20nntp-posting-host: rson.u.washington.in article <c5bf.iek@ms.uky.> billq@ms.uky. (billy quinn) writes:>i built a little project using the rao shack 5vdc lays to switch>auo.  i got ptty bad clicks when the thing switched. >	is the a good lay/lay circuit that i n use for switching>auo, so that the will be *no* noise of any kind on the auo lines.	with lays alone, you will always get a transient whenyou abruptly turn on or off any channel.  if you dont want to hearthe transient, use some other device (a photosistor-output optoisolatoris the usual sort of thing) to gently mute the signal, then switch,then move the power from the lamp in the optoisolator.	it used to be standard practice to emoy photosistorsin switching auo, beuse the photosistor time delay (a fewthousandths of a second) kept any noise in the gital side (whichdrives the lamp) from contaminating the auo.  and, the devicesa cheaper than lays.	john whio
